Photos in the
National Parks

2016 marks the 100th anniversary of the founding of the National Park Service. The parks continue to grow in popularity, with a record 307 million visitors in 2015. There are 411 park sites spanning over 84 million acres of US land. These include historic sites, lake shores, national monuments and, most notably, those sites designated as National Parks.

The National Parks preserve and protect our most important natural landscapes. The National Park Service is a network of over 20,000 employees, volunteers and partners, tasked with protecting these lands. They offer stewardship of the parks, in their words "...engaging communities through recreation, conservation, and historic preservation programs."

This project showcases a primary way in which people engage with the parks: through photos. Photography of the National Parks, immortalized by Ansel Adams, is now often shown socially through Instagram. In this project, we'll explore over 300,000 photographs, taken by hundreds of thousands of people, related to the parks. Below are the 10 most popular parks from 2015: choose one and begin exploring how and where people photograph the landscapes of America. Methodology and more statistics are below.

Explore a Park

Data & Conclusions

Inside the Numbers

How did those 330,000 posts break down? From that original number, xxx posts had location data, or about 50%. After filtering with geographic boundaries, we're left with 84,696 posts. The breakdown per park is to the right.

There is actually a negative correlation between the parks 2015 rank in popularity and the number of posts that fit out filter. There's several factors that could have influenced these findings. One is reception - posts without GPS data wouldn't have made it here, so poor coverage could have factored in. Another is frequency. Picking a finite amount of posts means that will stretch over different amounts of time per park.

Where Did the Locations Come From?

Location data in photos comes from the GPS in your phone in a process called geotagging. That data is then picked up in Instagram. This means our data is limited to photos taken where GPS was available.

This is data people allow to be shared, but don't always realize it is being shared. If that makes you uncomfortable, you can turn it off. This guide shows how to disable geotagging on an iPhone. If you only want to turn off geotagging in Instagram, check go here.

Data Sources

All data used in this project was gathered through the Instagram API, which provides access to all publicly-available posts. The data was gathered and parsed in python. This application is NOT live - collection took place on May 25-26th 2016. Instagram was announcing big API changes on June 1st, so I opted to collect all data before that date.

Methodology

The 10 parks chosen were the 10 most popular parks of 2015, ranked by total visitors.

The best method I found was to search by popular hashtags used in relation to each specific park. Gathering posts with a specific location tag (e.g. posts tagged at "Yellowstone National Park") results in all posts showing up at the same location marker. So after finding the popular hashtags for each park, I gathered 33,000 posts per park, for a total of 330,000. The dataset was filtered to remove posts that did not include location data, which averaged to about half (or ~16,000) of the posts. I then used Shape files, provided by data.gov, of the National Park boundaries. Using these boundaries, I could eliminate any posts that were not taken within the geographic boundaries of the parks themselves.

Was that the right method? I don't know, probably not. But it was the best approach I found. I'd love to hear if you have a better way.

Technical Explanations

My methods for collecting and parsing the data are also available in iPython notebooks on github here.
